bibl.title: Letter from Wilbur A. Sawyer to George K. Strode, May 6, 1948

div1.p: Sawyer writes Strode in an attempt to trace a missing books belonging to Agramonte Rodriquez Leon.

div1.head: Letter from Wilbur A. Sawyer to George K. Strode, May 6, 1948
div1.opener:
In reply refer to
IC 512.819
Dr. Leonard A. Scheele
xxxxxxxxxxxx
May 6, 1948.
My dear Dr. Strode:
div1.p:
The following is quoted from a letter of
April 30, 1948, from Dr. Philip S. Hench of the
Mayo Clinic, who is the principal speaker at the
Reed Commemoration Meeting on May 12:

"Last month in Cuba, I spent some
time with Agramonte's daughter, Senora
Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, Calle
K 254, Vedado, Havana, Cuba. She was
somewhat disturbed because she had not
had returned to her a book which she
loaned to someone indirectly as a result
of your correspondence with her about
the experiments of Agramonte on the monkey
of Rosalia Abreu. If I got my inform-
ation correct, as a result of your cor-
respondence with her, A Mr. Arden DuBois
arrived in Havana with a letter of intro-
duction from Doctor Crawford and borrowed
from ‘Miss’ Agramonte her book written
by some American psychologist from Yale
or Princeton, the book being on the Abreu
Collection of monkeys. Mr. DuBois never
returned the book. It was Miss Agramonte's
only copy. She didn't know the address of
Mr. DuBois or Doctor Crawford and is very
anxious to find out where the book is.

“I hope you know more about these people
than I do and can help her out.”

Dr. George K. Strode,
Director, International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
49 West 49th Street,
New York 20, New York.

I do not remember ever having seen the book in ques-
tion. Dr. Russell and I were anxious to discover the
origin of Dr. Agramonte's yellow fever-immune monkey
“Jennie”. This animal was mentioned in a reprint which
Dr. Agramonte sent us when we wrote him regarding the animal
experiments of the Yellow Fever Commission.

If the book in question can be identified and can be
purchased, it might be a good gesture to buy a copy and send
it to Senora Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon. I wonder if
the psychologist author was not Dr. Yorkes. Possibly Mrs.
Crawford would remember the episode, or Mr. DuBois.

If you have no information and will inform me, I shall
be glad to communicate with Mrs. Rodriguez Leon and, if
practicable, send her a copy of the book personally. Do
you have Mr. DuBois' address?
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Wilbur A. Sawyer,
Chairman, Program Committee. cc- Dr. Hench
